abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Protected Areas
            Development Project for Georgia were as follows: outcomes
            were moderately satisfactory, the risk to development
            outcome was moderate, Bank performance was moderately
            satisfactory, and Borrower performance was also moderately
            satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: in a country
            with no precedent for incorporating biodiversity
            conservation in spatial planning, it is unrealistic to
            expect that it can be achieved within the relatively short
            lifetime of a project. It is advisable to limit such
            activities to a pilot level to demonstrate their benefits.
            Establishing consultative bodies for protected area (PA) is
            not a guarantee that they will operate in a meaningful way.
            It takes substantial work and effort to develop adequate and
            country-specific tools for successful stakeholder
            representation in PA management. Top quality technical
            assistance from peer organizations coupled with adequate
            resources can significantly improve national standards and
            practice of PA interpretation and visitor management, by
            raising awareness about expectations of foreign visitors and
            modern international good practice. Competitive Grant
            Schemes (CGS) inevitably produces winners and losers. Full
            transparency of the decision-making process, a good public
            information system and appropriate community participation
            in the CGS cycle can help avoid the risk of turning losers
            into enemies of PAs and their administrations.

abstracts.cdata!:
Lagodekhi, the vast forest and wildlife
            shelter here, in the southern foothills of the Caucasus, was
            once a hunting reserve for 19th century Prince Demidov who
            would invite guests from France to shoot deer, lynx and
            bears. Established in the 20th century as a nature reserve,
            Lagodekhi became a sanctuary which only researchers and
            educators armed with permits could visit. Today, Georgians
            are working on the forest's third incarnation. Since
            2003, the park has been divided into a 2,000-hectare managed
            area, open to the general public; and a 22,000-hectare
            pristine nature reserve, off-limits to all but fauna.
            Lagodekhi is one of five protected areas in Georgia that
            have received funding from the Global Environment Facility,
            a pool of money managed by the World Bank and other
            international agencies that helps poorer countries reach
            higher environmental standards. The Protected Areas
            Development Project was designed to preserve Georgia's
            biodiversity by spreading environmental awareness,
            strengthening Georgias Department of Protected Areas and
            developing ecologically-friendly tourism. Georgia, a
            crossroad of European, Central Asian and Middle Eastern
            climates and terrains, is an important migration path for
            birds and mammals.

1121308.trustfund:
TF023968-GEF1 - GEORGIA : PROTECTED
            AREAS DEVELOPMENT PROJECT,TF039352-GEORGIA -  PROTECTED AREAS DEV. PROJECT,TF038117-GEORGIA BIODIVERSITY PROJECT,TF038053-GEORGIA - BIODIVERSITY,TF037684-ECA REGION - INDUSTRIAL
            POLLUTION, ETC.,TF037610-GEORGIA - BIODIVERSITY,TF020446-GEF1:PROTECTED AREAS DEVELOPMENT

abstracts.cdata!:
The Protected Areas Development Project
            will conserve biodiversity in Georgia, through the creation
            of three ecologically, and socially sustainable protected
            areas in forest ecosystems, and, build capacity for
            mainstreaming biodiversity conservation into production
            landscapes. The main components will: 1) support the
            development of a detailed plan for biodiversity, and forest
            conservation in the Central Caucasus region, and, support
            corridor conservation planning in Eastern Georgia.
            Biodiversity studies will be financed, and, a policy/legal
            framework will rationalize the mandates of the Framework Law
            on Protected Areas, and the Forest Code for the Central
            Caucasus; communal vegetation types, and rapid biological
            assessments will be mapped to implement corridor plans in
            the Eastern Caucasus Mountains; 2) establish protected areas
            management, and, build awareness of biodiversity
            conservation. Monitoring, and applied research will guide
            park management, and evaluate results of management actions,
            through the development of an information base, livestock
            assessments, and through special studies focused on species,
            plants, and animals to improve management decision-making.
            Training on protected areas management planning will be
            provided, to enforce ranger practices, and, enhance business
            planning; 3) reorganize, and strengthen the Department of
            Protected Areas, through: training in park administration;
            revenue account management; technical training in protected
            areas, and resource management; and, monitoring biodiversity
            programs; and, 4) finance project management, and operating
            costs within the Department of Protected Areas.

            AREAS DEVELOPMENT PROJECT,TF039352-GEORGIA -  PROTECTED AREAS DEV. PROJECT,TF038117-GEORGIA BIODIVERSITY PROJECT,TF038053-GEORGIA - BIODIVERSITY,TF037684-ECA REGION - INDUSTRIAL

repnme.cdata!:
Georgia - Protected Areas Development
            Project : environmental management plan

abstracts.cdata!:
This is an environmental management plan
            for Georgia's Protected Areas Development Project,
            improves the conservation and sustainable use of Georgian
            biodiversity. Negative environmental impacts include the
            following: The small-scale construction of infrastructure
            will have minor, short-term direct impacts on vegetation and
            local species-mainly due to soil excavation, dust, and
            noise. Increased recreational use of project sites may
            produce a direct impact because of under-management of
            tourist sites and facilities, possible overuse of campsites
            or trails, increased waste, harvesting of live wood for
            campfires, purposeful disturbance of wildlife, accidental
            fires, disturbance of flora and fauna, trespassing into
            fragile areas, and non-maintenance of trails lading to slope
            erosion. Mitigation measures include: incorporating
            environmental considerations into engineering design to
            ensure that waste is managed: waste bins, and technology for
            toilet facilities like leaching fields, organic composting,
            and septic tanks. To reduce pressure on overgrazed
            pasturelands, park administration will provide shepherds
            with basic extension services and provide basic veterinary
            assistance. Reducing the level of grazing through land
            zoning will reduce disturbances to wildlife, in particular
            the mountain goat. Shepherds will be allocated new grazing
            leases to replace existing leases within park boundaries.
